content.description:
At around 100 feet tall, this bolted route is a good romp for a budding leader.  While the bulk of the route is composed of step-like ledges and large knobs (5.5 or easier), there are two slightly more difficult sequences between the 1st and 2nd bolts and again just below the anchor (5.6).

This has generally good rock, but lichen abounds. There are some loose blocks on the arete climber's right of the route-- so watch out if doing TR variations.
content.protection:
7 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor (with rusty chains and crusty yellow webbing?? as of this entry).

There is a bit of a distance between bolts 6 & 7 which might give the new leader pause.
content.location: Walk 25 feet uphill from the roadway on the upstream side of the formation to find the small belay stance. Rap from the rusty chains.

content.description:
The Odyssey is a classic Luebben route from the early '90s. This is the left line in the topo of

Donâ€™t Damn It

.

Climb the face past two small roofs to the large roof. Make a long reach out the roof, and scamper to the anchors.
content.location: It is the right of three bolt lines tackling the roofs next to the highway (the left line is Craig's Quest, 13a/b, the middle line was is/was the open project)

content.description:
This is VERY well-protected, a nice route for beginning leader at the grade. It is a little dirty with lichen and road dust but overall a fun route with good holds and options the entire way up.

The first bolt is an easy 5.6 towards the right side of the face, then move up left towards the 2nd bolt. There is no real crux, just fun, well-protected moves the entire way up.

We rapped down from the 2 bolts at the base of the chimney and kinda barely made it to the ground with rope stretch on a 70m. It is recommended to walk off to the east after you top out through the super easy chimney.
content.protection:
6 bolts to 2 bolt anchor (there was another bolt leading into the easy chimney above).

Per

James Schroeder

: there are 12 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor these days.
content.location: This ascends the face right of the large roofs, just left of the left-facing corner. (I will add pics next time we drive by.)

content.description: This was an old project of Craig Luebben's. Craig's version goes right at the last roof to finish through some awkward chimney feature. I bolted the line directly up the beautiful steep arete that hangs over CO Highway 14.
content.protection: 9-10 bolts + a 2 bolt anchor. Several draws have permanent chain draws on them.
content.location:
Left of

The Odyssey

, climb easy terrain to a tricky move over a small roof. The crux comes right at the first roof - an inverted kneebar is crucial. More pumpy climbing on big holds with big span leads to the exposed finishing arete.

NOTE: this route will lower you right into the middle of the east bound lane of CO Hwy 14. You can clip back through the chain draws on the way down to avoid this.
